author: alexandair
body:
After updating PowerShell Core 6.0.4 to 6.1 in WSL (Ubuntu distro), I've noticed that I don't see what I type when I type parameter values.
Changing background color not to be black (default) revealed that parameter values are printed in black thanks to PSReadLine module.
Removing PSReadline module made everything visible again.

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body:
I think this is an issue with the Windows WSL default console color scheme.  If you look at the color properties:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5177512/45563333-444ed180-b80a-11e8-9b8d-a91ad8c85a49.png)

You'll probably see that DarkGray (index 8) is set to the same value as Black (index 0).  Try lightening the index 8 color (DarkGray) to 169,169,169 (hex a9a9a9).  That's why you can't see parameters (and operators) because PSRL is configured by default to use index 8 (or `` "`e[90m"`` - bright foreground).

You could argue that PSRL shouldn't use `DarkGray` given the WSL default colors but that should be submitted to the PSRL repo - which I have already done.  You can pile on here - https://github.com/lzybkr/PSReadLine/issues/744

comments.author: alexandair
rkeithhill
comments.body: Make sure you set the `Screen background` back to index 0 before closing the dialog.  Then it should look better.  But ultimately, perhaps PSRL should use a different parameter/operator fg color.

comments.author: alexandair
comments.body: @rkeithhill I forgot to mention that I don't see the same issue on PSCore 6.1 installed on Windows where background color is also black. Parameter values are here printed in bright color and are visible.

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body: The PowerShell Core console color config is different by default from the WSL color config.  So that doesn't surprise me.  I, OTOH, don't use the default PS Core color config.  I use `colortool` to set my color scheme to `OneHalfDark` and that does exhibit this same issue - Black and DarkGray use the same color value.

comments.author: taladar
comments.body:
The same issue (DarkGray being displayed as black) also affects Windows Powershell on Windows Server 2016 when used via Win32-openssh (as of version 8.9) and Powershell Core (as of 7.2.2) on Windows Server 2012 R2 and 2016.

A workaround is to add

```
Set-PSReadLineOption -Colors @{ "Parameter" ="`e[39m"; "Operator" = "`e[39m";"InlinePrediction" = "`e[39m" }
```

to your Powershell Core profile and

```
Set-PSReadLineOption -TokenKind Operator -ForegroundColor Gray\nSet-PSReadLineOption -TokenKind Parameter -ForegroundColor Gray
```

to your Windows Powershell profile on the affected systems.

title: [PSCore 6.1] In WSL, PSReadLine color for parameter values is black (doesn't work on default black background)
